title: Using Repurposed Materials
description: Building doesn't always require expensive or new materials. Our surroundings are full of valuable, reusable resources that — with the right mindset and care — can be turned into safe, durable, and dignified homes.

mindset.title: Foundations of the Right Approach

foundationOne.title: See value in leftovers
foundationOne.description: What others might throw away can often be reused for building, protection, or insulation.

foundationTwo.title: Examine material properties
foundationTwo.description: Make sure they are safe — free from harmful chemicals, mold, or sharp edges.

foundationThree.title: Be creative
foundationThree.description: Combining materials such as wood, metal, plastic, fabric, and cardboard can result in stronger and more functional solutions.

foundationFour.title: Adapt to local conditions
foundationFour.description: Materials differ between urban and rural areas — use what is easily available and environmentally friendly.

foundationFive.title: Prioritize safety
foundationFive.description: Reuse should never compromise stability or health — materials must be dry, sturdy, and non-toxic.

foundationSix.title: Think long-term
foundationSix.description: Good material choices not only provide immediate shelter but also ensure durability and easier maintenance.

mindset.conclusion: With this mindset, building becomes not merely a necessity but a creative, value-generating process — even in the simplest circumstances.

environment.title: Usable Materials in Our Environment
environment.description: Creating or improving a home doesn't always require conventional building supplies. In cities, a wide range of packaging materials and discarded items can be found and reused to make temporary shelters warmer, safer, and more comfortable.
environment.callToAction: Keep your eyes open as you walk the streets — notice what could help make your shelter waterproof, windproof, and better insulated. This way of thinking helps you see your environment differently and turn waste into valuable resources instead of letting it go to the landfill.

materialsSection.title: Available Materials and Their Use
materialsSection.description: Learn to look at your surroundings resourcefully — discover how everyday objects can be transformed into essential parts of a home.
materialsSection.availableDescription: Click on each material to learn more about its properties and uses

paper.title: Paper & Cardboard
paper.use: Layered cardboard provides excellent insulation. Can be used for wall panels, floor underlays, or temporary roofing when combined with waterproof layers.
examples: Cardboard boxes flattened and layered for wall insulation
Thick paper used as windbreak between wall gaps
Cardboard panels as temporary flooring over pallets
Paper stuffed into gaps for draft protection

metals.title: Metals
metals.whereToFind: Construction waste, scrap yards, discarded appliances
metals.use: Metal provides strength and weather resistance. Flattened cans make excellent roofing shingles, while wire and rods create structural reinforcement.
examples: Flattened beverage cans as waterproof roof tiles
Wire for tying structural elements together
Metal sheets as wind and rain barriers
Rods and bars for structural reinforcement

textiles.title: Textiles
textiles.rawMaterial: Old clothes, blankets, curtains, fabric scraps
textiles.whereToFind: Donation bins, discarded clothing, textile waste
textiles.use: Fabrics provide excellent insulation and can seal gaps. Layered textiles retain heat and block wind when used in walls or as door/window coverings.
examples: Old blankets hung as internal insulation layers
Fabric strips stuffed into wall gaps for sealing
Curtains used as door or window covers
Layered clothing in walls for thermal mass

plastics.title: Plastics
plastics.whereToFind: Packaging waste, construction sites, discarded containers
plastics.use: Plastic is waterproof and versatile. Bottles can be filled for insulation, sheets create vapor barriers, and foam provides thermal insulation.
examples: Plastic bottles filled with sand or straw for wall insulation
Plastic sheeting as waterproof roof underlayment
Styrofoam panels for thermal insulation
Plastic bags layered for wind and moisture barriers

wood.title: Wood
wood.whereToFind: Construction sites, shipping areas, furniture waste
wood.use: Wood is the primary structural material. Pallets become frames and floors, planks form walls, and branches can be woven for panels.
examples: Pallets as ready-made floor and wall frames
Wooden crates dismantled for planks and panels
Branches woven together for wall filling
Planks used for roof structure and support beams

modal.infoNote: Always inspect materials for safety before use. Avoid materials with mold, sharp edges, or toxic residues.
modal.examplesNote: These are practical examples. Be creative and adapt based on what materials you can safely access.

lookAround.title: Look Around With New Eyes
lookAround.description: Walk the streets with resourcefulness in mind. What seems like waste could be the key to making your shelter warmer, drier, and safer. This mindset transforms your environment into a source of valuable building materials.

recycling.title: Recycling and Reusing Materials
recycling.subtitle: Objects and discarded items around you can become valuable building materials if used creatively and safely.
principles: Observe the material's properties: Is it waterproof, flexible, heat-retaining, or rigid? Let this determine its use.
Clean and prepare it: Removing dust, mold, rust, or oil extends the material's lifespan.
Combine materials: For example, wood + fabric or cardboard + plastic sheet can improve insulation or strengthen structures.
Give materials a new purpose: A pallet can become flooring or wall panels; a plastic bottle can serve as roofing or insulation.
Design based on local resources: Consider what's available nearby — construction waste, packaging materials, or furniture panels.
recycling.conclusion: By thinking creatively and acting sustainably, even discarded materials can become the foundation of a safe and dignified home.
